Question of Franklin's visit to Vienna; adulation he will meet with; will try and prevent its being burdensome. Desired by Count Lacy, Maréchal of thier armies, to ask Franklin whether the famous sculptor, M. Ceraqui of Rome, could be employed in America for making statues, busts and monuments, which will doubtless be erected to thier eminent men. Regrets the choice of Ministers made by the King of England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Col. Matthias Ogden of the New Jersey Brigade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a letter which arrived for him from Vienna. Acknowledging his gift of the medal, a precious monument of a great epoch.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commanded several privateers under the American and French flags; account of his capture and imprisonment in England; obtained his liberty and returned to Dunkirk; out of employment and destitute of means; begs for a commission to sail under American colors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent Franklin's letter to the Baron de Rosencrone. Acknowledging the gift of the medal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deserted from the French service about forty years before; spent two years in Holland, and since then has been a citizen in America; question of his inheriting a French estate; begs Franklin to obtain the necessary letters of pardon to enable him to enjoy this inheritance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As the Chief Treasurer of the War Department in the Province of Brittany, sent many millions to Boston; in consideration of his services, asks that he may receive a medal celebrating America's independence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of François Geay's desertion from the French army; has fallen heir to an estate which he may not inherit because of this; begs Franklin to obtain his pardon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His desire to emigrate to America with his family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the petition [2p., dated March 12, 1784] presented to the Assembly of Pennsylvania, it being a joint request from the American Philosophical Society and the Library Company of Philadelphia for greater convenience in their accommodations; mentions certain lots on State House Square as most suitable for the design intended; opposition to this request; thinks a letter from Franklin arriving before the motion is made would have great influence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for letters of recommendation for Jacques Mazurié, who intends establishing a commercial house at Philadelphia. Apologizing for an indiscreet question he asked Franklin. Concerning certain French officers who were present at the defeat of Lord Cornwallis and who propose asking Franklin to present them with the medal; will dissuade them from this step if Franklin wishes it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin three hundred copies of the description of the medal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a petition from François Geay; does not doubt Franklin's kind interposition in the poor fellow's behalf. Sends him a small collection on the simplicity of the Christian religion, which is worthy of serious consideration; refers to certain events mentioned in those pages, especially to the killings of one hundred Christianized and friendly Indians by the whites. Pronounces a tirade against war. After teaching the youth of Philadelphia for nearly forty years, has obtained the office of teacher of the black children and others of that people; his opinion of the infamous traffic in slaves; intends publishing a paper on the evils of slavery; quotes the Abbé Paynal; strongly desires Franklin's return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill [1p.] against the Sicur Grive of New England, who bought certain merchandise of him, and then left without paying; begs Franklin to find out his present whereabouts.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Beyerlé de Fachevert, John Francis. Philadelphia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's kindness in furnishing him with letters of introduction for America; emboldened by this to ask his influence with his uncle, Major-General de Beyerlé, to send him enough money to purchase a piece of land and the animals, implements etc., to work it; begs Franklin to represent to his uncle the disagreeable consequences which will result from his refusal; may draw a letter of exchange on Franklin.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Wilkinson, William and Miss Wilkinson [Margaret or May ?]. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will do themselves the honor of dining with Dr. Franklin on the following Sunday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wants a loan, which his brother in America will refund. Encloses letter for his brother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for letters of introduction for Mr. Philip Nicklin, an English gentleman, who intends establishing, in Philadelphia, a house in the linen trade in connection with that of Dickinson, Lloyd and Nicklin in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thinks Franklin will find in his writings an excuse for the request he now makes for a medal celebrating the independence of America; it will be cherished in his family as an heirloom.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the desire expressed by M. Jerome Manfrin, a rich merchant of Venice, to entertain Franklin during his rumored visit to that city; charged with conveying this invitation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets to be unable to dine with Franklin to-day. Sends him some bottles of wine from the Canary Islands produced on the estate of M. de Cologan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a private interview with Frankllin as she is in need of his advice.
(In French.)
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. His time so limited that appointments to see persons on their private affairs often prove inconvenient; begs la Baronne to state her affair in writing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Always honored by Franklin's commands and ready to carry them out to the best of his abilities.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks questions relating to emigration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to give him a passport for his ship "La Capricieuse," and a letter of recommendation for her Captain.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sails for Boston by the first ship; business connected with Mrs. Mecom. Disappointment of Franklin's friends should he fail to visit England. If Franklin takes passage to Boston, begs that he will stay at his house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the inventor of a flying machine, which does not at all resemble Mr. Blanchard's; its construction will cost but ten louis; begs Franklin to defray this expense and enjoy with him the subsequent success.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning the Constitutions of the United States; these laws, if executed with the same spirit of philosophy and sound policy which framed them, will insure constant happiness to the country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just arrived from Philadelphia; if Franklin has any commands will be glad to execute them. Left Mr. and Mrs. [Richard] B(e)ach[e] well. Delighted at the report of Franklin's intended return to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers his services to America in his capaticy of surgeon; would like a position in some hospital or town.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Ginette frères and Luc Laugier. Marseilles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hoping that Franklin will forward their interests in a certain affair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Dainval, a merchant of Lyons, as Agent for the United States in the latter city. Is recommended also by the Marquis de Vergennes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches himself for not personally acknowledging the medal sent him by Franklin. Asks for letters for recommendation for the bearer, M. de Banne, who is about to sail for America.
(In French.)
A. E. by Dr. Franklin. Directing that he be given letters to Dr. [Samuel] Cooper, Gen. [Nathanael] Greene and Mr. [Robert R.] Livingston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes employment as Postmaster in the United States. Refers to secret information, in his possession, concerning the United States.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcribes a copy of his letter of January 31st, 1783; begs Franklin to answer it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Feels sure that Franklin will serve her father's unfortunate family; encloses a line from Mr. Fagan, certifying to her distress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the two free ports in Europe to be accorded to the United States; one must be on the ocean and the other on the Mediterranean; difficulty of making a wise choice among so many applicants; strongly in favor of La Seyne in the Bay of Toulon for the Mediteranean sea-port; tremendous advantage of its situation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to letter of May 15. Asks for £12 travelling expenses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of a friend, a surgeon who desires to pursue his calling in America in some assured position.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to help him to an occupation; his love of voyaging; difficulty of obtaining a place in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report that the United States intends having a quantity of cannon made France; offers to arrange the whole business.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Berruyer, -----, chevalier de. Chateau de St. Fromond

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his services in America; money he lost in these praiseworthy efforts; account of the whole affair, and the justice of his claims; begs Franklin to write to the French Ministers in his favor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Several things requiring the deliberation of the American Ministers; proposes a meeting at the Hotel du Roi the next day at eleven.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Clairval, Duchesac and Fauché de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's kindness in promising his protection for the establishment of a play-house in Philadelphia; report that many deputies from the United States are at present with Franklin; desires that his project may be placed before them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His services in American navy; imprisoned in England and escaped; married in Bedford Country; his destitute condition; begs assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his assistance in procuring her pension; the smallness of the sum does not impair her gratitude.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending to the law giver of the New World the first volume concerning the laws of the great people of the Old World. 1
(In French.)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 [De la Monarchie Françaisc et de ses Lois.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Takes this opportunity, by M. Du Chateau, to recall himself to Franklin's memory; begs for a few lines; has furnished M. Du Chateau with a set of wheels which will show his skill to be undiminished; encloses a list of his subscribers [1 p.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering his services to America as a surgeon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his civility; expects to bear witness to his many virtues in the places where he is going.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will dine with Dr. Franklin on the 25th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote on the 29th ult., requesting register for his brigantine; begs for a favorable answer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to procure a passage for his son, recall him from Geneva, and direct his embarkation to Boston; the boy's grandfather looks for him with no small anxiety; gratitude for the kindness shown his son by Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acceptance of Franklin's invitation by the Comtesse de Forbach; will bring her children if possible; if not, their place will be filled by M. le Baron de Wish.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, II, 263.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing [William] Bingham; if Mrs. Bingham accompanies him, warns Franklin against showing her such attentions as may deprive them too long of her society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the independence of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her husband, Thomas Holland, gave up his rank in the British army to fight for the Americans, and was killed during the war; left in a destitute condition with three children; begs Franklin to bring her case before Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His plan of publishing an American almanac in German, for the following year; among other things, it will contain a history of the Revolution and pictures of famous Americans; applies to Franklin for engravings of portraits, medals, uniforms, flags, etc; the histotical part of the almanac will be entrusted to Mr. Sprengel, Professor of history at the University of Halle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of the letters promised him as he leaves the next day for Lisbon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is to continue somewhat longer in his Office of Finance. Desires he would repeat his application for a loan in France, and hopes that, as the King's expenses are lessened, he may be able to comply with his gracious intention towards America; account of the distressed situation of America.
(Copy. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has distinguished himself at the University of Pavia; obliged through some family disgrace to leave Italy; begs Franklin's help in procuring him occupation in America.
(In Itlaian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His intention to embark for America in August, accompanied by a clerk, and to estalish a mercantile house in Philadelphia; in spite of a good fortune and good connections in Europe, would greatly prize some letters of recommendation to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for any news Franklin may have received of her brother; asks that her letters may be forwarded to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A minute account of the arrival in their harbor of the American schooner, "Nancy," John Gladin, Master, laden with tobacco from North Carolina; his reasons for believing that she intended smuggling every ounce of it upon some part of the Irish coast; steps he has taken to detain this vessel until further instructions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to appoint a time when he may show him his automatic chess-player, as well as another machine on which he has been working.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends him a letter for [William] Bingham; report that that gentleman has accepted a mission to one of the Courts of Europe; especially anxious to terminate the business before his departure.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Greyer, Herr. Minden on the Weeser

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was discharged from the postal service. Fears that he may not be reinstated. Wishes position in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a letter of recommendation for M. Berthier fils, who proposes to establish a commerical house in Philadelphia; his parents anxious that the young man should have one person in Philadelphia to whom he may apply for advice and assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring a passport for Germany via Strasbourg; would apply to the English Ambassador, but has omitted so far to pay his respects to him.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Chastellux, François Jean, marquis de. Marly-le-Roi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the note of which he spoke; hopes Franklin will obtain for his friends distinction which he so justly merits; his services in the American hospitals; owes his own life to him; his present close attendance at the sick-bed of one of his dearest friends. His high opinion of Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the son of the late Reverend Mr. [Thomas] Barton a clergyman of Lancaster; introduces his brother, Matthias Barton, who has been in business at l'Orient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In daily expectation of the arrival of two vessels from La Rochelle laden with salt, wine and brandy; their ultimate destination not yet decided; begs Franklin's advice as to where the best disposition of the cargo could be made.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a discovery of his; losing the honor and sacrificing the rewards; will confide the secret to Franklin and the methods by which he intends to use it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His plan to establish in America a manufactory of arms; his chances of success in Europe are mediocre; his desire to make terms with Congress which will be advantageous to both sides.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Gautier, a brother Mason, who desires the position of American Consul at Barcelona; politics does not enter into this request; their wish to oblige is their sole motive.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxious to know if the report of Franklin's visiting Venice has any foundation; his favorite study has been Natural Philosophy; the value which Franklin's conversation would be to him; if the report is false, will write down some of his ideas about the electric fluid and send them to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Called on him with letters of M[rs. Caty] Greene and Dr. [Samuel] Cooper, in reply to Franklin's letters of recommendation; desires greatly to talk with him about America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs to add to his friend [Charles] Spener's request, that any expense which Franklin may incur in sending the desired engravings, etc., will be met by M. Durand in Paris.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. [Jean Francois] Coste, a very clever physician; his services on behalf of the American soldiers and their love for him; the work he will show Franklin proves the esteem in which he was held.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Dr. Waring of South Carolina, who served his country faithfully and honorably during the war, and goes to Europe for his advancement in medical science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing three bills for Franklin's acceptance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hoped to find a position as messenger or mail-carrier; no vacancy left; begs Franklin's assistance to enable him to return to Morlaix.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for taking into consideration his request in favor of M. Dainval. Sends Franklin a draft of a commission such as could be given by Congress to M. Dainval, as Agent for the United States at Lyons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin's protection for one of his relatives, who desires to go to Boston and take up any work of which Franklin deems him capable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A second petition craving Franklin's assistance to enable him to return to America; treatment accorded him by Mr. Coffyn; believes he helps runaway English sailors in preference to Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advantages of promoting trade between America and Naples; places himself and his business house at Franklin's service; encloses a list of exports from Naples and Sicily, as well as the articles which Naples could import from America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
(Engraved.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation for Sunday the 8th.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Antonio Francesco Salucci et fils . Livourne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their vessel under the Tuscan flag, laden with oil, wine, silks, etc., has sailed for Philadelphia; prospect of advantageous commercial relations; the pirates of Barbary are the only draw-back; hopes the United States will soon make some arrangement with them which will remove this obstacle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appointing an hour for Franklin to come and see their work.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Dacier, Joseph Bon, baron de et al.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres to acknowledge Franklin's gift of the medal; regretting that it does not bear the name of the first and genuine author of the finest Revolution of modern times.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a plan conceived by himself and a friend to go to America and engage in commerce and agriculture; his intention to stay in France as their correspondent, and commercial agent, while his friend goes to America; begging for letters of recommendation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation for Sunday the 8th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin that he still lacks volumes 26 and 27 to complete his edition of the Dictionnaire des Sciences Morales, Politique, etc.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the copy of the Constitutions of the United States, and desiring to know if he has written to the Keeper of the Seals; also the number of copies wanted and the style of binding.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About to sail for Philadelphia; honored to receive Franklin's commands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a book which has just come out and is likely to make some noise. His intention of sailing for Philadelphia in July. Messages from Franklin's friends. Mr. [William] Strahan's attitude still inimical to the United States and to France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: For years, has written in the English newspapers upon public improvements; compares Paris in these respects most unfavorably with London; his interest in the American cause; begs Franklin to establish him in some occupation in France or America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to pay her a little visit; gives him the choice of several days.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent Franklin some time before a small manuscript work on electricity forwarded from Marseilles by a friend; begs for an answer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favor of the 22d ult. with his ducs for the Society of Antiquaries; number of prints owing Franklin. Kind messages to Mr. [Henry] Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him for a collection of his manuscripts on electricity.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarded to Paris all the letters entrusted to him for Franklin; possibility that Mr. [Robert] Morris reserved his letters for some quicker conveyance; left Philadelphia the morning after the declaration of peace, so that nothing material could have been done by Congress; has just been told that on April 24th Congress Resolved that British vessels should be given an entry. Death of Mr. Spalding and his attendant in a diving-bell off Dublin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note on the report on Oléron of which it was proposed to make a free port of trade for American shipping. Advantages of the port and neighboring town of Marennes, being the centre of a considerable export trade.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeating his request for payment of the sum due him by M. Grive.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Approbation of the design of soliciting benefactions for Dartmouth College, manifested by the Prince and Princess of Orange; nothing obtained from Amsterdam, but it succeeded well at Haarlem; desires a letter to Dr. [Richard] Price on behalf of the affair; expects to go to England in a fortnight; wishes to know if Dr. Franklin has heard anything favorable to the plan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Were prisoners to the English; have tried in vain to see [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.], the American Agent, or to get work; no money with which to pay their board; expect to starve in the streets; the other prisoners are on board Capt. Conyngham's ship, but he refuses to take any more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeats his question concerning the treatment which will be accorded French officers who have been employed in the service of the United States; came to France for his health on a year's furlough; does not wish to return without knowing what he may expect.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent Franklin a manuscript on the independence of North America; motive of this pamphlet. Obliged to leave Geneva; returned to London where he has lived for years; if Congress desires to do anything for him will be exceedingly grateful.
(In duplicate. In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him warmly for the letters to Messrs. Washington, Livingston and Morris, which will assure him the reception he so ardently desired.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His efforts to procure the information be desired; promise made by a certain person to cure him in some weeks; unpleasant effect of his first remedy; begs to know if he must abandon himself entirely to this person's advice; his eagerness to consult Franklin in person.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kindness to himself and his sons; expects to embark shortly for Philadelphia with his family. Expresses thanks for his repeated friendly and affectionate attention to each of his sons when on the Continent, which, if possible, he added to that respect, affection and reverence he has retained for him. The perpetuation of intercourse with him in America is one of the most valuable of the many advantages he expects to derive in that New World.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning possible commercial relations of the Palatine Electorate and the Duchy of Bavaria with America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Volmers, a member of one of the richest and most reliable houses in Bremen.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning several boxes addressed to Franklin and at present in Calais; begs for further instruction.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning L'Abbé Mical, who has just finished a remarkable piece of mechanism consisting of two heads which pronounce certain phrases; begs Franklin's and his grandson's presence at M. Mical's to dinner, where he will meet various Academicians, and may see the amazing invention.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not possible to confide to a letter that which she wishes to say to Franklin; begs therefore for an interview; desires him to enclose her letter to Mr. Martin in an envelope and forward it to the address given.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three inhabitants of Brussels desire to go to America; two to establish a manufactory of playing-cards, calico, etc.; the third is an able surveyor, linguist and solider; each desires an advance of 100 louis with the promise of the patronage of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation of dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that his former letter miscarried and that Franklin does not yet know of the "talking head" and his invitation to dine with the inventor.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Mascall, who is on his way to settle in Philadelphia; his steady upholding of the rights of the people, and his opposition to the measures of the Ministry, brought on him persecution and suffering from Lord Mansfield and other men in power; his knowledge of physics and chemistry, as well as of men and books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His journey and his arrival at dunkirk with his family and Mr. [Francis] Coffyn; expects to sail that afternoon; daily importunities which Mr. Coffyn experience from American seamen discharged from prison in England; strongly recommends him for the position of American Consul or Agent at Dunkirk. Enclosing an extract of letter from Commodore Jones, written on board the "Triomphant ," mentioning the presentation of the "America" to the King of France: his own attitude, his disappointments, his sailing as a volunteer on board the French fleet, and the handsome treatment he has received; messages to Franklin and to his Lodge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Favorable attitude of the Comte de Vergennes towards the Messrs. d' Eberstein; urges Franklin to demand certain concessions from Congress in their behalf, which the Comte de Vergennes will regard as an acknowledgment of the essential services which he rendered America; refers Franklin to Messrs. [Joseph Matthias Gérard] de Rayneval and Hénin in this affair.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending American gazettes to Messrs. Franklin and Jay.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the medal commemorative of the War of Independence. Promises a cordial welcome to any American citizens and their vessels who may visit the ports of his Island.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking Franklin for the medal commemorative of the War of Independence. Promises a cordial welcome to any American citizens and their vessels who may visit the ports of his Island.
(In French. Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to dine with Dr. Franklin on Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to grant Mr. Weinbrenner's request for letters of introduction for his Agent Mr. Donath. The cast of his profile which he sends, is made of plaster of Paris. Has at last received the first sheets of his book from M.Leègue. Hopes to see Franklin in Vienna before he sets out for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thinks he should have been entrusted with the despatches instead of Mr. [Samuel] Vaughan. Preliminary articles of peace received with joy. Attitude of Congress towards Franklin's request to come home; A[rthur] Lee's unsuccessful attempts to make up a party against [Robert] Morris and [Dr.] Franklin. Arrival of Capt. [Joshua] Barney and the "Washington" and the money safely deposited; credit of the bank at Philadelphia very good. The Constitution of Pennsylvania cannot be altered for two years. Heard that a salary was arranged for Franklin's grandson, but has forgotten the amount. Question of [Robert] Morris resigning his office. Sends a copy of the duties to be imposed by Congress. Desires Franklin to send him a "mittretain" for his ship "Olive Branch," otherwise he will be under the unhappy necessity of sailing under British colors.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Barclay, Thomas Mr. and Mrs. Auteuil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will dine with Franklin on Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desire a conference respecting the importation of goods into America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to send some pamphlets and newspapers. Begs Franklin to find out from [Robert] Morris what letters he sent over; suspects foul play.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On reading Franklin's letter, his admittance was celebrated with transports of joy; it was decreed that his picture, copied in miniature, was always to remain in their temple.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a work printed by order of the Trustees of the Collège de Louis le Grand; the author, M. le President Rolland has worked in defatigably for the education of the public; begs that the fruit of his labors may be sent to the [American Philosophical] Society at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Traded from Edenton, North Carolina, to the Island of Saint Eustatius for sixteen years; the fortune he made there was taken from him by Admiral Rodney when he took that Island; his present destitute condition; applies to Franklin for a little money; to ask such a favor is like death to him, but necessity knows no law.
A.E. by Dr. Franklin. "Cost a guinca."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
(Engraved.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has a collection of choice paintings of old and eminent masters. Wishes to exchange them for a country-seat in Georgia, Carolina or Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His services in the war, his imprisonment in England, his escape and enlistment in the French navy; his present destitute condition; begs Franklin to assist him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delay in sending the copies of the Constitutions of America, due to their having first been overlooked by the Comte de Vergennes; a second Franklin needed in Paris to do away with such shackles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Situation of Franklin's grandson in Geneva; fever from which he has suffered, caused by his close room and improper diet; strongly urges his removal; since writing the above, has brought the lad to Pent for the change of air.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting his invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has lost his fortune; begs Franklin to procure him some employment.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Stromeyer, F. and B. Straub. Strasbourg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request Franklin's intervention to secure payment of an account due them for a long time by Baron von Steuben for clothing furnished to the latter. Encloses promissory note for over £421 sterling signed by von Steuben.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the 20th of May, presented to Franklin a memoir, whose contents she hoped, would rouse his pity and gain his support; fears she was mistaken; begs for its return.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Can furnish explanations of different natural phenomena, which his discovery has enabled him to penetrate.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his immediate departure from Paris; offers his services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his son-in-law, John Carter, and Col. [Jeremiah] Wadsworth, of Hartford, who were joint agents in supplying the French troops; they go to France to solicit payment of the bills which have been drawn in their favor; begs Franklin's influence on their behalf. Congratulating him on the approaching peace and on his exertions to that end.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of two French Americans who desire to pay their respects to Franklin and dine with him on Friday or Saturday; one is her "grand garçon" and the other is the Comte de Feoren; if Franklin consents, she wishes to accompany them.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Barclay, Thomas Mr. and Mrs. Auteuil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His intention to go to America and raise potatoes; uses of this vegetable in feeding cattle; begs for information respecting its cultivation in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the "General Washington," Capt. [Joshua] Barney, from Philadelphia; consigned to his care as Agent for the United States at Havre; sends several letters to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was presented to him three years before by Commodore Paul Jones; their discussion concerning the qualities of a metal for sheathing ships; this new sheathing now carried to perfection; begs Franklin, when next he comes to Paris, to examine it at the house and talk the matter over.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring Franklin to procure employment in America for one of his friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a young relative who desires to enter the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. [Ph.] Thieriot who desires some letters of recommendation for America. Wishes to know if the sale of medicines of unkown composition will be allowed in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Song composed for the anniversary celebration of American Independence and Peace held at Benjamin Franklin's house at Passy [with corrections and additions by Abbé Morellet].
(In French.)

did.unittitle: to Benjamin Franklin and John Jay.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King is unable to grant their request for a sum of 1,900,000 livres as extraordinary relief, as he has not enough funds to pay the enormous expenses of the last war and is obliged to have recourse to loans.
(In French. Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin made an associate of the Académic [des Sciences, Belle-Lettres et des Arts] of Lyons. Their intention of calling on him very soon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to establish a library and printing-house at Philadelphia for one of his sons. Gives a list of German books which he wishes to send to Philadelphia. Asking permission to send him a copy of a military work by Baron O'Cahill which he thinks will be useful to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her frequent letters have never reached her son; begs Franklin, when he arrives in New York, to send the enclosed letter to her son, Paul Guillaume, and recommend him to the French Consul there in order that he may obtain a passage home; account of her son's services as a soldier.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Borges a merchant of Hamburg, freighted a vessel bound for Philadelphia with all his possessions, leaving nothing for his creditors; sends two letters from the Magistrates at Hamburg which he begs Franklin to forward; hopes by their means to recover what the thief carried off.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter of exchange drawn on Franklin which they desire him to accept and return.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the great events which have taken place; hopes his native country will learn the wisdom to be good. Compliments Franklin on his grandson [Benjamin Franklin Bache]; hopes his health will improve.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to go to the United States and establish a manufactory of arms; other associates who desire to go with him and establish different manufactories; begs for advice.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a gazette whose contents surprised him; has sent two of them to [Thomas] Mifflin in Congress; talked about it to some of the merchants; told their ships would be prevented by Congress from loading in the United States for the West Indies. Arrival of Mr. [William] Bingham and his lady.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Communicated his letter to the King and the draft of the proposed treaty of friendship and commerce. Sends a counter-draft drawn up by himself but not differing materially from Franklin's. Thinks it contains perfect reciprocity. Will do all in his power to accelerate the conclusion of the treaty.
(In French. Press copy.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres. of Am. Rev., Wharton, VI, 519.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a reply to the invitation to dine at Mme. [la Comtesse] de la Marcke's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bogs that the enclosed may be forwarded. Messages from Mr. and Mrs. [Michael] Hillegas and the young ladies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for the promised reply to his father's letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him two papers printed in the Philosophical Transactions; on his return to London promises to procure all the volumes due him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his business difficulties; if M. [Ferdinand] Grand cannot assist him, will let all his creditors fare alike; hopes he will not suffer in Franklin's esteem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks permission to sell 180 hogsheads of Jamaica prize sugars, on payment of the same duties levied on French sugars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Emperor of Morocco has appointed him to be the bearer of this letter to the United States, with whom he is willing to sign a treaty of peace and commerce; gave orders to the Captains of the men-of-war not to molest American vessels. He is to accompany to the Court of Morocco, the Ambassador that is to be appointed to conclude peace. Asks him to send the travelling expenses to him as such charges are to be paid by the country desiring the Emperor's friendship.
(In duplicate.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres. of Am. Rev., Wharton, VI, 549.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informed by M. [François Barbé] de Marbois, Secretary of the French Embassy in America, that Chevalier de la Luzerne desires an assortment of potherb seeds. Hears that the "Washington" is about to sail and that it is at Franklin's disposition; begs that the seeds may be forwarded by that vessel.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs to know if there is any chance of his gaining an honest livelihood in America; his position as Professor of Economics and Mathematics; his interest in theology.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He and two other American sailors have been prisoners in England and received their discharge some time ago; their fruitless efforts to procure a passage home at London, Dunkirk, and finally at Amsterdam; considers this hard treatment for men who risked their lives in defence of their country; depend on Franklin to extricate them from their forlorn position.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to accept and return the four enclosed bills as soon as possible.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In case [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.] should not provide for bills drawn by Mr. [Richard] Bache, thinks Dr. Franklin would desire to do it himself, in order to save Mr. Bache the dishonor and loss of their return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report that Franklin desires to establish glass-works in America; offers to furnish the kind of clay needed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote to him from The Hague concerning the furtherance of his plans; again begs to know whether anything can be done in France towards the accomplishment of his object.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remind Franklin that there is still due to them by the United States, a balance of over 846,000 livers on the advance of 1,000,000 made by them for shipments of tobacco not completed. Refrained from pressing their claim during the war and do not ask any interest on the money, but request a prompt settlement either in cash or in tobacco.
(In French. Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Visit paid him by Mr. Silas Deane; understands he wrote part of the pamphlet sent to Franklin; cannot esteem him as before, now that he goes with [Benedict] Arnold and Lord Sheffield. Dr. [Edward] Bancroft is applying to go to Philadelphia; distrusts his motives. Messages from Mr. [John] Sargent. Begs for news of public matters in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Various ways in which he has been of use to subjects of the United States; asks for the position of Vice-Consul at Morlaix; his zeal in the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mme. de Frère, being obliged to take a short journey, desires him to return the enclosed bill.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A glowing tribute to Franklin. His occupation that of a doctor as well as priest. Describes the plan of a picture which he wishes to present to Congress; this will represent the heroes of the American war, the traitor Arnold, the victim André, the brutality of the English, the mediation of France, and Heaven's approval of the struggle for liberty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his brother, Mr. Benjamin Austin, Jr. and Mr. Oliver Brewster, two young gentlemen who are making a tour of Europe. Congratulating Franklin on the peace and on his own distinguished part in that glorious event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Benjamin Austin, Jr., a brother of Mr. [Jonathan Loring] Austin who carried the news of Burgoyne's surrender; recommends him most warmly to his notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [Oliver] Brewster who goes to England with Mr. [Benjamin] Austin and thence to France on mercantile affairs; the particulars regard he has conceived for this young man justifies this recommendation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes in the name of the Committee of Correspondence appointed by the delegates of forty-five Volunteer Corps; their determination to procure a more equal representation in Parliament; depraved state of their present representation; desires Franklin's opinion and advice as to the best means of countcracting the corrupt borough influence; puts the whole matter into eight queries to which they beg answers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin that the meeting to be held in his house will be held in the house of the Spanish Ambassador.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests an interview with Franklin about an unfortunate man in whom she is interested.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is one of a numerous family; would like to sail for the United States with a recommendation from Franklin and the assurance of a salaried position; is even willing to till the fields; if possible, would like to stay for a time in Paris and pursue his study of English at the Sorbonne; in that case would be glad to share the food of Franklin's servants.
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to call on Franklin in company with M. [Ph.] Thieriot of Leipsic, who goes to Philadelphia as a commercial agent of Saxony.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Corntesse de Deux-Ponts hopes to visit Franklin after her return from Versailles; in the meantime, she begs for a medal in place of the one she gave M. de Vauban, and also the return of Les Nouvelles Littéraires which she sent Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Griffin Green[e], lately arrived from America, a near relative of Gen. [Nathanael] Green[e].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires his opinion on the chief cause of the suffering experienced by the garrison of St. Philips; believes it was their omitting to preserve a free current of air through their subterranean lodgements. Introducing Partick Wikil, Esq., who goes as Consul to Alicante; hopes of seeing Franklin in London; glad that the remembrance of a most agreeable fair one is still with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his intended departure for London early in the following week; offers to take charge of the letter to Mr. [John] Calder, as well as any Mr. [John] Adams or Mr. and Mrs. [John] Jay care to send.
(In duplicate.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Montcarel, Jean-Jacques Le Goüeslier de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a packet which was forgotten when the despatches were sent to be forwarded to M. de la Luzerne; if not too late, begs it may be sent, and the oversight not mentioned to M. [Joseph Matthias Gérard de Rayneval.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the receipt of the Constitutions of the United States; expressing his appreciation of such a mark of attention.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the copies of the "Constitutions," one for his King, one for himself and one for M. Filangieri; Sensible of the honor Franklin has done him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Argental, Charles-Augustin Ferriol, comte d'. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging with extreme satisfaction the copy of the Constitutions of the United States which Franklin has sent him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Boufflers-Rouvrel, Marie-Charlotte-Hippolyte de Campet de Sanjon, comtesse de. Auteuil

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's precious gift, with every expression of gratitude.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his gift with the liveliest expressions of gratitude; reminding him of his promise to visit her in the autumn.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the "Constitutions of the Thirteen United States of America."
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the copy of the "Constitutions" of the United States sent him by Franklin; the copies destined for the King, Queen and Royal Family will be faithfully delivered.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The most unfortunate of patriots is obliged to apply to the most illustrious; although in disgrace, still wishes to be useful; his principal bent is towards agriculture; has written a trcatise on this science; desires to place his talents at the service of America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two vessels lately sailed for Philadelphia with upwards of two hundred passengers. Account of an American vessel, the "Nancy," being detained in the harbor of Castleton nearly ten weeks; wrote Mr. [Henry] Laurens of this; advises an application for redress to the British Court; other vessels had all their loose tobacco seized by Revenue Officers; necessity of America having a Consul at Cork; state of the laws in Ireland as regards the sale of tobacco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a gentleman of quality, formerly a French officer, who desires to settle with his wife in America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Ormesson, Henri-François de Paul Le Feurè d'. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the copy of the Constitutions of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Franklin a copy of the last ordinance concerning the trade of the Islands of St. Thomas and St. Johns [2p.], also a list of the principal merchants in the Danish West Indies (2p.). The Island of St. Croix and their trade with America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Rochambeau, Jean-Baptiste-Donatien de Vimeur, comte de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs to have the enclosed letter forwarded to the Chevalier de la Luzerne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging a number of introductory letters which has been productive of pleasure of profit. The bearer is Mr. [John] Carter by whom he sends a bundle of newspapers; Mrs. Carter is the daughter of Gen. [Philip] Schuyler, a lady too well known to Franklin to need a recommendation. Has received the Loan Office Certificate for another year's interest on the money lent the public by Franklin. Glad to know when they may expect him home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recounts the legend concerning the purchase of the Sibylline books; the printed discourse which he sends Franklin of far more value than vain oracles; the system of Legislations on which he has worked for seven years will put the seal on the liberties of America.
(In French. In Duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith at Rome has deemed it advisable to appoint a Bishop in some city of the United States as Apostolic Vicar with spiritual jurisdiction over all the Catholics in that country and invested with power to ordain priests. requests Franklin to transmit his note on the subject to Congress.
(In French. Press copy.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diploma. Corres. of Am. Rev., Wharton, VI, 614.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to send the enclosed letter to her friend Mr. [James] Hunter [of Richmond, Va.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the desired permission to enable Franklin to remove a packet of books from the custom-house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consultation with his creditors; their desire that his letter of surséance be renewed for a year; desires Franklin to make the application for him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the affairs of [Jonathan] W[illiams] and the terms of payment offered, to which most of his people have agreed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About to leave for the country; sends some letters for America, and begs that the replies may be forwarded to the address given.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggests the importance of establishing commercial relations between America and the principal German towns on the Rhine and Main; recommends a friend as an Agent in these towns. Enumeration of products.
(In German.)
The same
(Translation in French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to honor with his attention the enclosed memoir.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to honor his last with some kind of an answer; if his request is not granted, entreats some kind of assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their project to establish glass-works in America; privileges which they would ask of Congress; begs Franklin's advice on this subject; enclosing a detailed plan [4p.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ode to Liberty composed in honor of Benjamin Franklin on receiving from him the medal struck by the Congress of the United States in 1782.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting an audience with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards a letter from the General Post Office and has paid the deficient postage. Probable that many letters may come for him with the inland postage unpaid. Inquires if he shall take them up and forward them. Will be happy to be useful to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Henry Smeathman, a protégé of Dr. Fothergill, who visited the Coast of Africa and wishes to suggest new ways of extending trade in that continent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires recommendations to American mercantile firms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The business which her husband transacted in America in 1777 is the reason for her requesting an immediate audience with Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to establish a market in America for the sale of his wines.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging enthusiastically the copies of the Constitutions, one for the King of Poland and one for himself.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Ambassador of the States-General. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of an armonica made from Franklin's model; account of various inventions by M. Landriani of Milan. Description of a piece of Polish money of the 15th century, found shut up in a rock. Reason given for the natural formation of a hill on the banks of the Elbe. They now possess an excellent translation in German of Franklin's works. Enthusiastic praise for Franklin and for the great Nation he has helped to found.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Renews his offers of service in his capacity of engineer and architect.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charged with affectionate farewells by the Comtesse de Deux-Ponts, who goes to Tugny to attend the wedding of her son, and thence to Forbach. His regard for Franklin is a sort of hero-worship. The "America" arrived at Brest; her construction much admired.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charge against Lord Shelburne of having used foul play about the instructions for removing the troops from New York; second charge that he put the Spaniards in possession of Florida to give them an opportunity of quarreling with the America; gives his reasons for not believing these accusations; thinks Lord Shelburne would never be relished by Frenchmen or by ambitious English placemen; believes him to be a fair-meaning, bold statesman. [End of letter missing.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to his bankruptcy; his creditors have expressed confidence in him. Expects to be able eventually to satisfy them all.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Remmel, J. Chrétien and Houba, Jean

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apply for a free passage to America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Perier, -----, baron de. Chateau d'Ussan at Pau

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The cargo on his vessel he was forced to sell at New London for paper money; wishes Franklin's assistance to redeem the amount.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Charged by M. Bournons of the Royal Academy of Sciences at Brussels to send Franklin the first part of his "Eléments de Mathématiques"; promises the next two volumes when they appear. Describes how he has improved the armonica; will gladly come to Passy and give him a practical demonstration.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring when he could see Franklin at Passy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs permission to dedicate to him a few little books, intended to facilitate the acquisition of the Roman language. The letter he received from Franklin when a prisoner at Valognes in Normandy he destroyed as a precautionary measure; is now en route to Portsmouth, Va., and would very much like another letter from him, in order to procure a professorship in one of the American colleges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His share of prize-money due him as doctor on board "La Vengeance"; Commodore Paul Jones. Desires a place as physician to the Americans, who are about to found an institution at l'Orient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [Le] Grand Cannon from Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Russell of Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of the action of Dr. Franklin's grandson [William Temple Franklin] in taking away a miniature portrait of Lady Nicolson and insists on its prompt return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeats his request for Franklin's protection and advice as well as letters of recommendation to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to know if he may expect Franklin at his house on Wednesday morning; afterwards they must go to the Military School and to the Invalides, relative to the lightning-rods which the Maréchal de Ségur intends erecting on those two buildings; after this inspection, Le Gouverneur des Invalides desires Franklin's presence at dinner. Franklin will see at M. Brongniart's house the model of the projected column to the glory of Louis XVI.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Samuel Cooper] Johonnot arrived too late for the last vessel to New England; will try to get him a passage to Philadelphia; poor opinion of his father.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to procure a passage for [Samuel Cooper] Johonnot at a smaller rate; thinks it will prove cheaper in the long run to send him off at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know about the prize-money due Messrs. Gognet and Cossont, officers on board the "Pallas" under the command of Paul Jones.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a book he has sent Franklin containing directions for using his patent electrical machine; the experiments in the philosophical part tend to confirm Franklin's theory of electricity, and the similitude of lightning and electricity. Account of an electrical storm in Oxfordshire which killed thirteen sheep, every one of which had the balls of their eyes forced out.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His arrival at Nantes; his passage to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the medal and Franklin's favor of May 16th. Delay in the printing of his book; acknowledging Franklin's permission to dedicate it to him. His opinion of the biography of Sir John Pringle by Dr. [Andrew] Kippis, his theological friend, who contributed to fix his anxious mind upon "Socinianisme" as being, in his opinion, the most rational and the only good religion. A paper he intends writing for which he desires philosophical anecdotes about Franklin; begs for a description of the two electrical explosions by which Franklin was hit; description of a like experience to himself; 1 received a severe electric shock whilst making experiments in electricity. Was rendered unconscious for ten or fifteen minutes. Highly injurious effects he felt mentally and physically on first regaining consciousness. After twentyfour hours experienced renewed vigor and great improvement in all his mental faculties; felt much better and stronger than before the shock. Thinks the insane might perhaps be restored to their mental faculties by an electric shock administered to them. Would not however advise anyone to try it on himself. Wishes to publish Franklin's invention of a clock with only three wheels, as well as the curiosity of the globe; begs for his reflections on chimneys. Chances of a war with the Turks, and the danger of having the plague; their custom of fumigating all letters from the East; this is now to be abolished; bewails this criminal act. Application made to him by the Princess of Lichtenstein to intercede with Franklin on behalf of lady [Juliana] Penn. No satisfactory news from Mr. [Samuel] Wharton or [Francis] Coffyn; cannot believe the former is a sharper. Newspaper report that the American people are unwilling to contribute anything to support the public credit.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 Translation in French of this account, 4p. (In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Baynes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests an audience to confer on the best means of forming an establishment in Virginia or Pennsylvania.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the sixty bottles of wine ordered; desirous of supplying the Americans with wines.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deplorable situation of the American merchants in France; due entirely to the peace; Mr. Grubb's failure; gives him the highest character; recommends Mr. Harrison, who was for some time in Mr. Grubb's office.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: J.A.C. Sieck formerly Postmaster at Goettingen. Berlin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a position in the young Republic. Is able to give valuable secret information concerning the American Revolution. Refers to a previous letter to Mr. Adams. Mentions Secretary Bonhome in the Dutch secret service.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing certain letters for Mr. St. John.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reported concessions granted by Congress to would-be settlers in America; has the honor to be a French officer of good family but no fortune; desires to know what kind of a reception he may expect in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of the author, M. Telles Dacosta, sends Franklin a book about woods.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his kindness in signing his marriage contract; his approaching wedding and the numberless matters incidental thereto must excuse his not pressing the contract in person.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning an old debt due for shipping some articles to Mr. Richard Bache of Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by the Royal Society of Medicine to send Franklin tickets for their public meeting on the 26th; the Society hopes Franklin will be present; intends reading a eulogy on the late Dr. [Sir John] Pringle.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After thirty years, has brought to perfection his invention for grinding corn; his successful experiments in preserving grain and flour; the results of his work can be found in the printed memoir subjoined.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a family at Tournay, whose talents are as unusual as their ill-fortune has been great. Their knowledge of the manufacture of silk and linen, etc.; if an opportunity should offer to employ them in the service of America, begs Franklin to let him know.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to send the enclosed to the Chevalier de la Luzerne, which includes some lines to his American friends.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the copy [of the Constitutions of the United States] sent him by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requested by his nephew (John M[arsden] Pintard) to beg an introduction for the house of Mr. John Searle and Co., in Madeira; extreme attention paid by this firm to American prisoners who were carried to that island.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter in favor of Mr. [Burrill] Carnes; thinks if Franklin writes directly to the Comte de Vergennes, the safe conduct will be granted him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning Franklin the first project for the definitive treaty [of peace with Great Britain]. Encloses a copy of a prescription for gravel; hopes it will be of benefit. Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.]'s affair will come before the Council on the 29th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his letter of August 19th. By mistake it was sent under address of Mr. Dumas at The Hague. Encloses duplicate of said letter.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request made in Franklin's name by the Duc de la Rochefoucauld for twelve copies of the "Constitutions." Repeats his wish for an interview.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that a multiplicity of business has prevented Franklin from answering his last two letters; begs for a little pecuniary assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if it will be perfectly agreeable to Franklin to present him to the King on the following day; the Marquis de la Fayette will be present at the ceremony; if it is not inconvenient, begs for a seat in Franklin's carriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting the position of Consul at Genoa for M. Aimé Bonnafons.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the copies of the American Constitutions sent him by Franklin; much concerned to hear of his indisposition.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presents the claim of an American sailor called Springer, now at Brest, against a certain man, Lelay, who had collected 2,496 francs from the French Admiralty for Springer's account. The claim arose from the sale of a sloop seized in the cove of Cork by seven American sailors who were escaped prisoners from an English jail. The sloop was declared a lawful prize by the French Admiralty and ordered sold, the proceeds to be distributed amongst the seven sailors. Lelay who collected Springer's share as attorney for the latter refused to turn over to him the full amount of his share. Asks Franklin to intervene.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his fault and promising to profit by it. Expects to sail with the first fair wind.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His desire to obtain advancement at Court; wishes particularly to interest in the Comte de Vergennes in his behalf; begs Franklin to write the Count a letter; enumerates his services to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of a letter which was to be sent to the Hotel d'Espagne for Lieut.-Gen. Melville, and which never came to hand; the bearer, Mr. P. Elmsly will carry any letters Franklin may care to send to London.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Platen, M.E., douairière de. Gartz in Rugen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for news of her son, Philip de Platen, who left France seven years before, to enter the service of the United States; since then has heard nothing of him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of his promise to subscribe to their encyclopaedia of thirty-six volumes; desires his assistance in order to encourage the sale of this work in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About to sail, in the ship "Nancy," for Philadelphia; pleased to be honored with Franklin's commands.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin the quarto copy [of the American Constitutions] for the Grand Duke of Russia, and also the one in octavo.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Durey de Meinières, Octavie Guichard. Aux Pavillons du Chaillot

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a copy of the "Constitutions" translated by M. de la Rochefoucauld; hears it cannot be bought; would be proud to possess a copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait on Franklin on Thursday and receive his commands for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Williams unable, so far, to trace the whereabouts of her husband whose late letter, dated 1778, spoke of sailing for Boston; her miserable situation, deprived of a support, if he is living, and of his effects, if he is dead; encloses a memoir containing all the details [3p.]; begs Franklin's assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulates him on his recovered health; begs him not to forget his offer, in case Congress desires to erect any monuments to the glory of the Nation or to the Generals who contributed thereto.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In praise of Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for acquiescence in his request to be sent to Congress with the definitive treaty; as Mr. Jay has declared himself decidedly in favor of Mr. Adam's clerk, begs Franklin not to trouble to propose him; will inform the Marquis de la Fayette what deference Franklin paid to his recommendation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desire of Count Chotek, Chancellor of Bohemia and Austria, to have the enclosed list of American plants sent to a good botanist who will at once forward the grains of seeds to Amsterdam. Urges Franklin to finish his glorious career in philosophical tranquility. His hopes of seeing Franklin in Vienna. Contented with what he has acquired by saving the most illustrious Princess of the world from a disease so fatal to her family; he enjoys in philosophical obscurity more real happiness than a conqueror of a world.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
